newsitem.title: UK: FEATURE - Truce collapse puts N.Irish police in front line.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Truce collapse puts N.Irish police in front line.

text.p: Most police give photos of their passing out parades pride of place in their homes. Not in Northern Ireland.
Here they are hidden in drawers so that no unannounced visitor will ever know that there is a member of the Royal Ulster Constabulary (RUC) in the house.
Every day they they peer under their cars for booby-trap bombs. Only close neighbours know what their occupation is. The tell-tale green police shirts are rarely on the washing line.
A year after Irish Republican Army (IRA) bombs blew holes in a peace process, Northern Ireland's police are back on the front-line of a growing guerrilla war.
"We're back to where we were," a veteran officer said ruefully about the collapse of an IRA ceasefire on February 9, 1996, and violence that could dump war on his doorstep.
POLICE THE MAIN TARGET OF IRA
The IRA bombing of London's Canary Wharf complex one year ago heralded the end of a 17-month truce and the start of a new campaign to drive Britain from the province.

Bomb attacks in the northern English city of Manchester and a British army base in Germany followed quickly but since October last year the IRA has concentrated on Northern Ireland and the RUC in particular.
"When the Canary Wharf bomb went off in London this time last year, my heart sank. I thought to myself we're on a slide. It's starting again'," recalled the officer, who asked not to be named.
He had seen at first hand the depths of the 1969-1994 IRA guerrilla war that erupted in daylight on street corners or along dark country lanes in a conflict that killed 3,200.
Officers torn apart by guerrilla rockets. Bewildered parents being led into hospitals to identify loved ones found bound, gagged and shot, victims of sectarian murder gangs.

A senior British security source said IRA "volunteers" have been told by their commanders to attack Northern Ireland soldiers and police officers, preferably while on duty and in uniform, in an escalation of a war to end British rule. "The threat is high against security forces right across the province," the source told Reuters.
"The IRA is quite well supplied. Alongside all their commercially-produced weaponry, they have also always relied heavily on home-made weapons which are just as effective."
CANARY WHARF WRECKS PEACE DREAM
The Canary Wharf explosion killed two civilians and caused millions of pounds worth of destruction in the heart of one of the British capital's key financial districts.
It wrecked an Anglo-Irish peace process, ended the longest truce the IRA has ever called, and set the province back on the slippery slope towards renewed sectarian war as a way of life.
In 25 years the RUC lost 297 officers and hundreds more were badly wounded, largely at the hands of IRA bombers and gunmen.

The truce by the IRA, which draws support from Northern Ireland's 40 percent Catholic minority, was followed by one from pro-British Protestant Loyalists, which threw the troubled province a lifeline.
The 92 percent Protestant RUC turned to "normal policing" and got on with passing out speeding tickets but simmering tensions led to sectarian clashes last summer.
Many in the Catholic minority accused the RUC of bias and of using heavy-handed tactics to ensure the passage through Catholic districts of several contentious Protestant parades.

Distrusted by sections of Catholics and regarded by many Protestants as a bulwark for preserving treasured British links, RUC officers say they have been pitched into a no-win position in the middle of age-old rivalries.

They say they help the whole community preserve order and defeat crime but IRA guerrillas, and a growing Loyalist menace, are forcing them into a high profile counter-insurgency role they hoped had been left behind.
TRUCE MEANT "FALSE SENSE OF SECURITY"
"We were lulled into a false sense of security," said a policewoman in a country station. "Now it's slipping back."
The IRA staged its first attack for two years in the province in October, killing one soldier and wounding 30 with a car bomb at British Army headquarters in Lisburn near Belfast.

Since December the guerrillas have stepped up mortar and grenade attacks on both police and British soldiers. To date they have killed no one, but police say it is a matter of time. The main threat is at security patrols or bases, but police officers are stepping up personal and domestic safety measures.
Cadet graduation pictures are locked in drawers for fear of unexpected callers. Children are reminded not to leave doors open and not to talk too much about "what dad does".

"You try to strike a balance between not being careless and being alive to the fact that there are people who would maybe go to your house and plant a bomb under your car or shoot at your home," a long-serving officer said.
In the past, RUC men and women have been ambushed on and off-duty, in their homes, in security bases, in bars and on their way to church.

When the IRA called its truce the RUC shed their bulky flak jackets and high calibre arms. For the first time in a quarter of a century they patrolled without army support in areas that had been war zones. Now they are back on alert.
Gingerly they patrol hostile Irish republican strongholds on foot or in in bleak grey bullet-proof vehicles. Military armour backs them up, helmeted soldiers riding shotgun.
The onset of a potentially explosive Protestant "marching season", which saw Loyalist hardliners attack them last summer, will see them in riot gear again this year.
"We had let ourselves become a lot more relaxed during the ceasefire," a middle-rank officer said wistfully.
"It was like having a weight lifted off our sholders. The prospect of facing back into a war situation - well, its really dreary and depressing."
